article.headline: Panthers hold Scarlet Knights to 14 first-half points

images.name: Krauser Carl 030222 inline
images.caption: Pittsburgh's Carl Krauser, left, scores over Rutgers' Adrian Hill. Krauser, with 11 points, was one of five Panthers in double figures.

article.linkText: No. 9 Pittsburgh's defense, depth overpowers Rutgers
article.story: PITTSBURGH (AP) -- The defense is there, just as it was a year ago when Pittsburgh won 29 games. What's new is the depth, and that's what coach Ben Howland said separates this team from the squad last season. Pittsburgh, the Big East's top defensive team, held Rutgers, the conference's worst offensive team, to 14 points in the first half and the No. 9 Panthers cruised to an 86-65 victory Saturday night. Pitt (19-4, 9-3) moved into a three-way tie with Notre Dame and Syracuse for the Big East West Division lead by winning its 20th consecutive home game. No Panthers player reached double figures until Julius Page hit 11 points with 11:13 remaining, yet Pitt still led by as many as 31 before the game got sloppy. Nine Pitt players scored at least six points. ''We're definitely better than we were a year ago,'' Howland said. ''That was a great first half defensively. You couldn't ask for more. We played good defense, we shared the ball offensively and we played unselfishly. That's our game.'' Pittsburgh is 19-4 for the second consecutive season. The Panthers' best record after 23 games was 22-1 in 1973-74, when they advanced to the NCAA quarterfinals. They went undefeated in 1927-28, but played only 21 games. Point guard Brandin Knight didn't realize how well Pitt was playing until he realized that, with only eight minutes left before halftime, Rutgers had only eight points. ''We've had some games where we played well in spurts and then let up, but we played exceptionally well at the defensive end,'' Knight said. ''We played every possession and made stops. We didn't let up in the first half.'' Knight credited Page for harassing Rutgers' Jerome Coleman into an 0-for-7 shooting night. Coleman was averaging 17.2, but didn't score. For Pitt, Ontario Lett finished with 13 points and combined with Chevy Troutman to shut down Rutgers inside early, allowing the Panthers to surge to leads of 16-6 and 23-9. ''It was a very bad-looking game,'' Rutgers coach Gary Waters said. ''It's one of the worst I've been involved in. They took us out of everything we tried to do. ... I've never been involved in this kind of (bad) performance before.'' Pitt came in allowing a league-low 59.1 points and Rutgers was averaging a league-worst 67.3 points, so it was predictable the Scarlet Knights would have trouble opening up their offense until the game was long since decided. Usually limiting the Knights (11-13, 3-9) to one shot per possession -- and, often not a good one -- the Panthers held Rutgers to 21.7 percent shooting in the first half and 36.1 percent overall. The Knights, last in the division and in danger of missing the Big East tournament, also had some other unenviable statistics at halftime: 13 turnovers and no assists. They finished with 18 turnovers and five assists. Calvin Wooten scored 21 and Herve Lamizana had 17, but Rutgers still lost its third in a row and 10th in 13 games. The Knights lost their fifth in a row to Pitt. Pitt had five double-figure scorers in its third consecutive relatively easy victory, with Jaron Brown getting 12, Page and Carl Krauser 11 each and Troutman scoring 10. The Panthers beat West Virginia 82-46 Feb. 12 before winning at Georgetown 82-67 on Tuesday. It didn't matter that Knight, coming off a season-high 23 points against Georgetown, again wasn't much of a factor offensively with six points. The Big East's preseason player of the year, Knight came in averaging 9.7 points, the lowest average among Pitt's top six players. The Panthers are two victories from sweeping their 16-game home schedule in their first season at the Petersen Events Center. Their remaining home games are against Connecticut and Seton Hall, with Virginia Tech and Villanova on the road. For now, Knight isn't ready to agree with Howland that Pitt is better than a year ago, when it went 29-6 and reached the NCAA round of 16. ''Last year, we finished it out, winning our last seven conference (regular season) games,'' Knight said. ''We've still got four tough games to play, and we want to close out our season the way we did last year.''
